title: Estimating Age-Depth Models from Sedimentation Rates
text: vignette explains estimate age-depth models (ADMs) sedimentation rates using function sedrate_to_multiadm

title: Estimating Age-Depth Models from Sedimentation Rates
text: sedrate_to_multiadm function estimates age-depth models sedimentation rates position timing tie points. takes following inputs encode user knowledge: h_tp : function encoding stratigraphic positions tie points t_tp : function encoding times tie points sed_rate_gen: function encoding sedimentation rates change stratigraphic positions. information can example derived cyclostratigraphic analyses. addition, takes following inputs specify estimation procedure: h : vector heights ADM determined no_of_rep: integer, number runs

title: Estimating Age-Depth Models from Sedimentation Rates
text: Times heights tie points coded via functions t_tp (timing) h_tp (height) take inputs. serve wrappers around user-defined procedures reflect uncertainties around tie points. Every time t_tp h_tp evaluated, return possible values tie points. Writing functions requires effort, allows user hand arbitrarily complex uncertainties tie points sedrate_to_multiadm function. function timing tie points must return vector increasing times. example, assume first tie point follows normal distribution mean - 20 Myr present standard deviation 0.5 Myr. timing second tie point bimodal given equal mixture two normal distributions means - 5 - 7 Myr years present standard deviations 0.1 0.3 Myr years. implemented follows t_tp: Sampling t_tp yields following empirical distribution tie points:  function heights tie points must return ordered vector stratigraphic positions tie points. number stratigraphic tie points time tie points must identical. example, assume stratigraphic positions tie points known without uncertainty, 10 85 m stratigraphic height. h_tp implemented follows: evaluated, function returns stratigraphic positions tie points: lot effort simply encode fixed stratigraphic positions tie points. However, allows implement arbitrary uncertainties position tie points needed.
code: t_tp = function(){   # first tie point   t1 = rnorm(n = 1, mean = -20 , sd = 0.5)      # second tie point   d1 = rbinom(n = 1, size = 2, prob = 0.5) # fair coin flip for mixture   if (d1 == 0){     t2 = rnorm(n = 1, mean =  - 5, sd = 0.1)   } else {     t2 = rnorm(n = 1, mean =  - 7, sd = 0.3)   }   return(c(t1, t2)) } no_of_samples = 10000 # Evaluate timing of tie points hist(x = sapply(seq_len(no_of_samples), function(x) t_tp()[1]),      freq = FALSE,      xlab = "Time before present [Myr]",      main = "Timing of first tie point") hist(x = sapply(seq_len(no_of_samples), function(x) t_tp()[2]),      freq = FALSE,      xlab = "Time before present [Myr]",      main = "Timing of second tie point") h_min = 10 # height of tie point 1 h_max = 85 # height of tie point 2 h_tp = function(){   return(c(h_min, h_max)) } #Evaluate stratigraphic positions of tie points h_tp() #> [1] 10 85

title: Estimating Age-Depth Models from Sedimentation Rates
text: Sedimentation rates specified via function sed_rate_gen takes inputs. serves wrapper user-defined procedures specify uncertainties sedimentation rates. sed_rate_gen “function factory”: every time evaluated, returns another function one potential sedimentation rate scenario. Writing function factory requires effort, allows user specify uncertainties sedimentation rates expressed section, implement arbitrarily complex distributions. idea behind sedimentation rates considered stochastic processes. Every time sed_rate_gen evaluated, returns one sample path process. functions returned sed_rate_gen must return strictly positive values - negative sedimentation rates can observed section. use simple sedimentation rate model, upper lower bounds sedimentation rates section known. limits, assume uniform distribution. Based parameters, sedimentation rate function factory defined follows: visualize, three sedimentation rates generated “sedimentation rate function factory” sed_rate_fun:  sedimentation rates generated sed_rate_fun different, determined random numbers.
code: # limits on sed. rates lower_limit = c(0.1,2,0.1,10) upper_limit = c(0.2,3,2,12)  # strat intervals where sed rates are defined s = c(h_min, 30,65, 80, h_max) # define function factory sed_rate_fun = function(){   # draw sed rates from uniform distribution   aa = runif(n = length(lower_limit),              min = lower_limit,              max = upper_limit)   # define sed rate "realization" based on samples from uniform distribution  sed_rate_fun = approxfun(x = s,                           y = c(aa, aa[length(aa)]), # duplicate right most value bc of step function, see ?stats::approxfun for details                           method = "constant",                           rule = 2, #extrapolate outside of domain of definition, see ?stats::approxfun                           f = 1) # left continuous function  # return the function  return(sed_rate_fun) } plot(NULL,      xlim = c(h_min, h_max),      ylim = c(0, max(upper_limit)),      xlab = "Stratigraphic Height [m]",      ylab = "Sedimentation Rate")  no_of_sedrates = 3 # no. of sed rates displayed h = seq(h_min,h_max, by = 0.1) # strat. positions where sed rates are plotted  for (i in seq_len(no_of_sedrates)){   # generate sed rate from the factory   sed_rate_sample = sed_rate_fun()      # plot sed rate in the section   lines(h, sed_rate_sample(h)) }

title: Estimating Age-Depth Models from Sedimentation Rates
text: function sedrate_to_multiadm estimates age-depth model inputs. , determine age-depth models every meter, generate 10 ADMs generates portfolio age-depth models combined variable madm (multi-adm). madm object class multiadm.  10 age-depth models generated sedrate_to_adm function, equally likely candidates age-depth relationship section. Running summary statistics large number age-depth models (increasing no_of_rep input variable) gives assessment uncertainties age-depth relationship. can used generate classic envelopes uncertainty (95 % CI).
code: h = seq(h_min,h_max, by = 1) # strat. positions where ADMs are estimated no_of_rep = 1000 # no. of ADMs estimated my_adm = sedrate_to_multiadm(h_tp = h_tp(),                              t_tp = t_tp(),                              sed_rate_gen = sed_rate_fun,                              h = h,                              no_of_rep = no_of_rep,                              L_unit = "m",                              T_unit = "Myr BP")

title: Estimating Age-Depth Models from Tracer Contents of Rocks and Sediments
text: vignette gives example estimate age-depth models (ADMs) tracer contents rocks sediments using function strat_cont_to_multiadm. function takes following inputs: h_tp : function returns stratigraphic height tie points t_tp : function returns times tie points strat_cont_gen : function returns tracer contents observed section, outcrop, drillcore time_cont_gen : function returns tracer input sediment changed time h : vector heights ADMs estimated no_of_rep : integer, number age-depth models determined

title: Estimating Age-Depth Models from Tracer Contents of Rocks and Sediments
text: Assume tracer embedded rocks sediment (e.g. Pollen, extraterrestrial 3He, etc.). addition, information temporal variations tracer available. tracer values measure sediment can compared assumed input flux tracer construct rates sediment accumulation, age-depth model can constructed. standard example tracer input sediment constant. high tracer values reflect low rates sediment accumulation, equivalent low gradient age-depth model. idea formalized using idea stratigraphic content time content: Stratigraphic content tracer value measured section (units tracer per length unit), time content input tracer sediment (units tracer per time unit).

title: Estimating Age-Depth Models from Tracer Contents of Rocks and Sediments
text: Times heights tie points coded via functions t_tp (timing) h_tp (height) take inputs. serve wrappers around user-defined procedures reflect uncertainties around tie points. Every time t_tp h_tp evaluated, return possible values tie points. Writing functions requires effort, allows user hand arbitrarily complex uncertainties tie points strat_cont_to_multiadm function. function heights tie points must return ordered vector tie point heights. example, assume stratigraphic positions tie points known without uncertainty, 10 20 m stratigraphic height. h_tp implemented follows: evaluated, function returns stratigraphic positions tie points: function timing tie points must return vector strictly increasing values corresponding times tie points. example, assume timing first tie point follows normal distribution mean 0 standard deviation 0.5. second tie point, maximum minimum time available. Due lack information, assume uniform distribution minimum (9) maximum (11). implemented follows t_tp: Using Myr time unit, distribution times tie points follows:
code: h_min = 10 # stratigraphic height of lower tie point [m] h_max = 20 # stratigraphic height of upper tie point [m] h_tp = function(){   return(c(h_min, h_max)) } h_tp() #> [1] 10 20 t_tp = function() {   # timing first tie point   t1 = rnorm(n = 1, mean = 0, sd = 0.5)      # timing second tie point   t2 = runif(n = 1, min = 9, max = 11)      return(c(t1, t2)) }

title: Estimating Age-Depth Models from Tracer Contents of Rocks and Sediments
text: stratigraphic contents age contents must coded function factories, .e., functions return functions. must able take vector inputs return vector length output. assume tracer input sediment constant time. implemented following function: visualize , let’s plot time 0 10: implementation tracer values can simplified using helper functions flux_const, flux_linear, flux_quad wrappers define constant, linear, quadratic changes tracer flux time. tracer measured section, assume measured bottom, middle, top examined section: locations, tracer values follow normal distribution mean 10, 1, 8 standard deviations 1, 0.1, 0.2. assume measured points, tracer values change linearly. assumptions values, function factory tracer can coded follows visualize , 3 possible scenarios tracer values change section:
code: time_cont_gen = function(){   time_cont = approxfun(x = c(0,10), y = c(1,1), rule = 2)   return(time_cont) } # generate one function from time_cont_gen time_cont = time_cont_gen() # time where to evaluate the function t = seq(0,10,by = 0.1) plot(x = t,      y = time_cont(t),      type = "l",      xlab = "Time [Myr]",      ylab = "Tracer Input into the Sediment [1/Myr]") locations = c("h_1" = h_min, "h_2" = mean(c(h_min, h_max)), "h_3" = h_max) mean_vals = c("mu_1" = 10, "mu_2" = 1, "mu_3" = 8) sd_vals = c("sig_1" = 1, "sig_2" = 0.1, "sig_3" = 0.8) strat_cont_gen = function(){    loc = locations    trac_vals = rnorm(n = length(mean_vals),                      mean = mean_vals,                      sd = sd_vals)    strat_cont = approxfun(x = loc,                           y = trac_vals,                           yleft = trac_vals[1],                           yright = trac_vals[3])    return(strat_cont) } n = 3 # number of sampled tracer values  h = seq(h_min, h_max, by = 0.1) # determine age-depth model every 0.1 m plot(NULL,      xlim = c(h_min, h_max),      ylim = c(0, max(mean_vals) +2 * max(sd_vals)),      xlab = "Stratigraphic Height [m]",      ylab = "Measured Tracer [1/m]") cols = c("red", "blue", "black") for (i in seq_len(n)){   strat_cont = strat_cont_gen()   lines(x = h,         y = strat_cont(h),         col = cols[i]) }

title: Estimating Age-Depth Models from Tracer Contents of Rocks and Sediments
text: input data coded, age-depth models can estimated using function strat_cont_to_multiadm. , determine age-depth models every 0.25 m, generate 10 ADMs estimated age-depth model can handed plot display :
code: h = seq(h_min,h_max, by = 0.25) # strat. positions where ADMs are estimated no_of_rep = 1000 # no. of ADMs estimated my_adm = strat_cont_to_multiadm(h_tp = h_tp,                                 t_tp = t_tp,                                 strat_cont_gen = strat_cont_gen,                                 time_cont_gen = time_cont_gen,                                 h = h,                                 no_of_rep = no_of_rep,                                 T_unit = "m",                                 L_unit = "Myr") plot(my_adm, mode = "envelope") T_axis_lab() # plot time axis label, see ?T_axis_lab for details L_axis_lab() # plot length axis label, see ?L_axis_lab for details make_legend() # make legend

title: adm_plotting
text: vignette describes plotting options plotting age-depth models.

title: adm_plotting
text: example, use age-depth model taken 4 km offshore carbonate platform modeled using CarboCAT Lite (Burgess 2013, 2023). data provided package. adm can directly plotted using standard plotcomman R. can modified using arguments listed ?plot.adm  prefixes lwd, lty, col stand line width, line type, color respectively. suffix destr destructive intervals, suffix acc intervals sediment accumulation.
code: adm = tp_to_adm(t = CarboCATLite_data$time_myr,                 h = CarboCATLite_data$height_4_km_offshore_m,                 L_unit = "m",                 T_unit = "Myr") plot(adm,      lwd_destr = 1,      lty_destr = 4,      col_destr = "blue",      lwd_acc = 1,      lty_acc = 1,      col_acc = "black")

previous_headings: Plotting age-depth models > Simple age-depth models (class “adm”)
title: adm_plotting
text: Axis lables can added using functions T_axis_lab (axis label time axis) L_axis_lab (length axis label). default, use units associated age-depth model object. behavior can overwritten using labeland unit options. details, see help page ?T_axis_lab L_axis_lab. example, plot accumulating parts, add axis labels. ## Multiple age-depth models (class “multiadm”)
code: plot(adm,      lty_destr = 0,      lwd_acc = 3) T_axis_lab(label = "Elapsed Model Time") L_axis_lab(label = "Stratigraphic Height")

title: admtools: Getting Started

title: admtools: Getting Started
text: Load package using makes functions package available.

title: admtools: Getting Started
text: Use get overview available help pages package, view simple help page package. Vignettes long form package documentation provide detailed examples. list available vignettes, use
code: help(package = "admtools") ?admtools browseVignettes(package = "admtools") # opens in Browser #or vignette(package = "admtools")

title: admtools: Getting Started
text: admtools package defines three main classes: adm, sac multiadm. class adm represent single age-depth model, information can extracted (e.g. completeness, number hiatuses, etc.) can used transform data stratigraphic domain time domain. multiamd class list adm objects. multiadm objects used represent uncertainties age-depth models. Objects type sac sediment accumulation curves can contain information erosion, can turned age-depth models.

title: admtools: Getting Started
text: contrast name, admtools package currently deals time height instead age depth. sense, age-depth models time-height models. time height can negative values. handle ages, use time present. handle depths, use height point reference (e.g., sediment surface).

title: admtools: Getting Started
text: example explains construction application adm objects. example data use outputs CarboCAT Lite, model carbonate platform growth (Burgess 2013, 2023). data automatically loaded background package. get info data use

title: admtools: Getting Started
text: standard constructor age-depth models tp_to_adm (“tiepoint age-depth model”). returns objecto class adm. object combines information stratigraphic heights times erosive interval. allows transform data stratigraphic time domain, identify data destroyed due hiatuses. example, use timing stratigraphic positions tie points taken CarboCAT Lite construct age-depth model, use option directly associate length time units . age-depth model represents relationship elapsed model time accumulated sediment 2 km offshore synthetic carbonate platform.
code: # see ?tp_to_adm for detailed documentation my_adm = tp_to_adm(t = CarboCATLite_data$time_myr,                   h = CarboCATLite_data$height_2_km_offshore_m,                   L_unit = "m",                   T_unit = "Myr")

title: admtools: Getting Started
text: Typing name my_adm console tell generated variable age-depth model get quick overview properties my_adm, use summary: want inspect insides object, use str: can manually manipulate fields adm object treating like list. recommend , might result unexpected downstream behavior. can plot adm objects via standard plot function. , use option highlight hiatuses red, increase linw width conservative ( = non-destructive) intervals.
code: my_adm #> age-depth model summary(my_adm) #> age-depth model  #> Total duration: 2 Myr #> Total thickness: 146.0621 m #> Stratigraphic completeness: 32.65 %  #> 10 hiatus(es) str(my_adm) #> List of 5 #>  $ t     : num [1:2001] 0 0.001 0.002 0.003 0.004 0.005 0.006 0.007 0.008 0.009 ... #>  $ h     : num [1:2001] 0 0 0.609 1.095 1.722 ... #>  $ destr : logi [1:2000] TRUE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE FALSE ... #>  $ T_unit: chr "Myr" #>  $ L_unit: chr "m" #>  - attr(*, "class")= chr "adm" # see ?plot.adm for plotting options for adm objects plot(my_adm,      col_destr = "red",      lwd_acc = 2) T_axis_lab() # plot time axis label, see ?T_axis_lab for details L_axis_lab() # plot height axis label, see ?L_axis_lab for details

title: admtools: Getting Started
text: Use functions get_total_duration, get_total_thickness, get_completeness, get_hiat_no extract information: detailed information, can use get_hiat_duration get vector hiatus durations get_hiat_list get list hiatus positions duration. example, plot histogram hiatus durations, use  function is_destructive can used examine whether points time coincide hiatuses:
code: get_total_duration(my_adm) #total time covered by the age-depth model #> [1] 2 get_total_thickness(my_adm) # total thickness of section represented by the adm #> [1] 146.0621 get_completeness(my_adm) # stratigraphic completeness as proportion #> [1] 0.3265 get_incompleteness(my_adm) # stratigraphic incompleteness (= 1- strat. incompleteness) #> [1] 0.6735 get_hiat_no(my_adm) # number of hiatuses #> [1] 10 hist(x = get_hiat_duration(my_adm),      freq = TRUE,      xlab = "Hiatus duration [Myr]",      main = "Hiatus duration 2 km offshore") is_destructive(my_adm,                t = c(0.1,0.5))  #> [1] FALSE  TRUE

previous_headings: Introduction > Representation > Transforming data between time and stratigraphic domain
title: admtools: Getting Started
text: functions get_height get_time workhorses transform data using age-depth models. get_time takes adm object vector heights h (stratigraphic positions), returns vector times get_height takes adm object vector times returns vector associated positions example, say want know time deposition following stratigraphic positions: Conversely, determine parts section deposited specific time, use , NA indicates time 1.4 coincides erosion. want know stratigraphic position hiatus coincides time, use option destructive = FALSE:
code: h = c(30,120) # stratigraphic positions get_time(my_adm,          h = h) #> [1] 0.1380552 1.2704696 t = c(0.2,1.4) get_height(my_adm,            t = t) #> [1] 39.13951       NA t = c(0.2,1.4) get_height(my_adm,            t = t,            destructive = FALSE) #> [1]  39.13951 126.27764

previous_headings: Introduction > Representation > Transforming data between time and stratigraphic domain
title: admtools: Getting Started
text: admtools package can transform complex objects time stratigraphic domain. done using functions strat_to_time time_to_strat. example, transform chronogram (phylogenetic tree branch length represents time). , first generate tree following birth-death model using ape package.  can transform tree using time_to_strat: Plotting resulting tree along tratigraphic column shows evolutinoary relationships preserved 2 km offshore simulated carbonate platform:
code: #install.packages("ape") Package for analyses of phylogenetics and evolution # see ?ape::rlineage for help set.seed(1) tree_in_time = ape::rlineage(birth = 1.8,                              death = 0.2,                              Tmax = 2) plot(tree_in_time) # see also ?ape::plot.phylo axis(1) mtext("Time [Myr]", side = 1, line = 2.5) tree_in_strat_domain = time_to_strat(obj = tree_in_time,                                      x = my_adm) plot(tree_in_strat_domain, direction = "upwards") axis(side = 2) mtext("Stratigraphic Height [m]",       side = 2,       line = 2)

previous_headings: Introduction > Representation > Transforming data between time and stratigraphic domain
title: admtools: Getting Started
text: admtools can transfrom lists time height domain vice versa given elements names h t. lists can interpreted time/stratigraphic series, times stratigraphic positions associated measured values. Note t objects used stats package, generally heterodistant due hte irregular nature age-depth transformation. example, simulate trait evolution 2 Myr using Brownian motion, transform simulation stratigraphic domain.   Note jump traits generated erosional interval my_adm.
code: t = seq(0, 2, by = 0.001) # times BM = function(t){   #" Simulate Brownian motion at times t   li = list("t" = t,             trait_val = cumsum(c(0, rnorm(n = length(t) - 1, mean = 0, sd = sqrt(diff(t))))))   return(li) } evo_list = BM(t) plot(x = evo_list$t,      y = evo_list$trait_val,      xlab = "Time [Myr]",      ylab = "Trait Value",      type = "l") strat_list = time_to_strat(obj = evo_list,                             x = my_adm) plot(x = strat_list$h,      y = strat_list$trait_val,      type = "l",      xlab = "Stratigraphic Height [m]",      ylab = "Trait Value",      main = "Trait Evolution 2 km Offshore")
